canonical_explanation.text: Geometry begins with the basic ideas of points, lines, and planes. A point has no size, a line extends infinitely in both directions, a ray starts at a point and goes infinitely in one direction, and a line segment has two endpoints. Curves can be open or closed, and closed curves like polygons have an interior, exterior, and boundary. A circle is a closed curve where every point is at the same distance from the centre.
rules: Rule 1: A line has no endpoints and extends infinitely; a ray has one endpoint; a line segment has two endpoints
Rule 2: Intersecting lines meet at a point; parallel lines never meet; perpendicular lines meet at 90 degrees
Rule 3: A polygon is a closed figure made of line segments — sides meet at vertices
Rule 4: Number of diagonals in an n-sided polygon = n(n-3)/2
Rule 5: Circle: diameter = 2 x radius; a chord is any segment with endpoints on the circle; the longest chord is the diameter

questions.question_text: A line segment has:
questions.explanation_correct: A line segment is a part of a line with two definite endpoints.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A line has no endpoints, a ray has one endpoint, and a line segment has exactly two endpoints.

questions.question_text: How many lines can pass through a single point?
questions.explanation_correct: Through a single point, infinitely many lines can pass in all directions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Only through TWO points does exactly one line pass. Through a single point, infinitely many lines can be drawn.

questions.question_text: A ray has two endpoints.
questions.explanation_correct: A ray has only ONE endpoint (the starting point) and extends infinitely in one direction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A ray starts at one point and goes on forever in one direction, so it has only one endpoint.

questions.question_text: How many lines can pass through two given points?
questions.explanation_correct: Through any two distinct points, exactly one line can be drawn.
questions.explanation_incorrect: One and only one line passes through two distinct points. This is a fundamental principle of geometry.

questions.question_text: Two lines that never meet are called:
questions.explanation_correct: Parallel lines are lines in the same plane that never meet, no matter how far they are extended.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Intersecting lines meet at a point. Perpendicular lines meet at 90 degrees. Parallel lines never meet.

questions.question_text: Two intersecting lines meet at how many points?
questions.explanation_correct: Two distinct intersecting lines meet at exactly one point, called the point of intersection.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Two straight lines can intersect at most at one point. (If they meet at more, they are the same line.)

questions.question_text: Perpendicular lines form an angle of:
questions.explanation_correct: Perpendicular lines intersect at right angles, which measure 90 degrees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The defining property of perpendicular lines is that they meet at 90 degrees (right angles).

questions.question_text: A closed curve divides the plane into how many parts?
questions.explanation_correct: A closed curve divides the plane into three parts: the interior, the exterior, and the boundary (the curve itself).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Three parts: inside (interior), outside (exterior), and the curve itself (boundary).

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a polygon?
questions.explanation_correct: A polygon is a closed figure made entirely of straight line segments. A triangle is the simplest polygon (3 sides).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Circles, semicircles, and ovals have curved edges. Only a triangle is made entirely of straight lines — it is a polygon.

questions.question_text: A polygon with 5 sides is called a ___.
questions.explanation_correct: A 5-sided polygon is called a pentagon (penta = five, gon = angle).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Names: triangle (3), quadrilateral (4), pentagon (5), hexagon (6).

questions.question_text: How many diagonals does a quadrilateral have?
questions.explanation_correct: A quadrilateral has 4 vertices. Diagonals = 4(4-3)/2 = 4/2 = 2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A quadrilateral has 2 diagonals connecting opposite vertices.

questions.question_text: The sum of angles of a triangle is:
questions.explanation_correct: The sum of interior angles of a triangle is always 180 degrees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The angle sum property of a triangle: all three angles always add up to 180 degrees.

questions.question_text: In a circle, the distance from the centre to any point on the circle is called the:
questions.explanation_correct: The radius is the distance from the centre of a circle to any point on the circle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The radius connects the centre to the circumference. The diameter goes through the centre from one side to the other.

questions.question_text: The longest chord of a circle is:
questions.explanation_correct: The diameter is the longest chord of a circle. It passes through the centre.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A chord is a line segment with both endpoints on the circle. The longest such segment passes through the centre — the diameter.

questions.question_text: If the radius of a circle is 7 cm, its diameter is ___ cm.
questions.explanation_correct: Diameter = 2 x radius = 2 x 7 = 14 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Diameter = 2 x radius = 14 cm.

questions.question_text: Which of these extends infinitely in both directions?
questions.explanation_correct: A line extends infinitely in both directions. A ray extends infinitely in only one direction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A line segment has two endpoints, a ray has one. Only a line has no endpoints and extends both ways.

questions.question_text: An angle is formed by:

options.text: Two rays with a common endpoint
Two line segments with no common point

questions.explanation_correct: An angle is formed by two rays sharing a common endpoint called the vertex.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Two rays starting from the same point (vertex) form an angle. The rays are the arms of the angle.

questions.question_text: How many sides does a hexagon have?
questions.explanation_correct: A hexagon has 6 sides (hex = six).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hexagon comes from 'hexa' meaning six. A hexagon has 6 sides, 6 vertices, and 6 angles.

questions.question_text: The sum of angles of a quadrilateral is:
questions.explanation_correct: The sum of interior angles of a quadrilateral = (4-2) x 180 = 360 degrees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A quadrilateral can be divided into 2 triangles, so angle sum = 2 x 180 = 360 degrees.

questions.question_text: A chord that passes through the centre of a circle is called:
questions.explanation_correct: A chord passing through the centre is the diameter. It is the longest chord of the circle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A chord through the centre = diameter. A radius goes from centre to circumference (not a chord).

questions.question_text: Give an example of parallel lines from everyday life.

options.text: The two hands of a clock at 3 o'clock
The two rails of a railway track
The two diagonals of a square

questions.explanation_correct: Railway tracks are a classic example of parallel lines — they run side by side and never meet.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Clock hands intersect at the centre. Diagonals of a square intersect. Triangle edges meet at vertices. Railway tracks are parallel.

questions.question_text: A triangle has how many vertices and sides?
questions.explanation_correct: A triangle has 3 sides, 3 vertices, and 3 angles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A triangle ('tri' = three) has 3 of everything: 3 sides, 3 vertices, 3 angles.

questions.question_text: The number of diagonals in a triangle is ___.
questions.explanation_correct: A triangle has 3 sides. Diagonals = 3(3-3)/2 = 0. No diagonals can be drawn in a triangle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A diagonal connects non-adjacent vertices. In a triangle, every pair of vertices is connected by a side, so there are 0 diagonals.

questions.question_text: A part of the circumference of a circle is called:
questions.explanation_correct: An arc is a part (portion) of the circumference of a circle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A chord is a straight line between two points on the circle. An arc is the curved part between two points.

questions.question_text: Three or more lines passing through the same point are called:
questions.explanation_correct: Lines that pass through the same single point are called concurrent lines.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Concurrent means meeting at one point. Collinear means points on the same line.

questions.question_text: Two lines in a plane must either be parallel or intersecting.
questions.explanation_correct: In a plane, two distinct lines are either parallel (never meet) or intersecting (meet at one point). There is no third possibility.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Two lines in the same plane have only two options: they intersect or they are parallel.

questions.question_text: A diagonal of a polygon connects:

options.text: A vertex to the midpoint of the opposite side

questions.explanation_correct: A diagonal is a line segment that connects two non-adjacent (non-neighbouring) vertices of a polygon.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sides connect adjacent vertices. Diagonals connect non-adjacent vertices.

questions.question_text: The region enclosed between a chord and an arc is called a:
questions.explanation_correct: The region between a chord and the arc it cuts off is called a segment of the circle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A sector is enclosed between two radii and an arc. A segment is enclosed between a chord and an arc.

questions.question_text: Which of these is an open curve?

options.text: A wavy line from A to B

questions.explanation_correct: An open curve does not close back on itself. A wavy line from A to B (where A and B are different) is open. Circles, triangles, and rectangles are closed curves.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Open curves have endpoints that do not meet. Circles, triangles, and rectangles are closed curves.

questions.question_text: Points that lie on the same line are called:
questions.explanation_correct: Points that lie on the same straight line are called collinear points.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Collinear = on the same line. Concurrent = lines passing through the same point. Coplanar = on the same plane.

questions.question_text: How many diagonals does a pentagon have?
questions.explanation_correct: Pentagon has 5 sides. Diagonals = 5(5-3)/2 = 5x2/2 = 5.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using the formula n(n-3)/2: 5(5-3)/2 = 10/2 = 5 diagonals.

questions.question_text: Which letter of the English alphabet has perpendicular line segments?
questions.explanation_correct: The letter L is made of two line segments meeting at a right angle (90 degrees), forming perpendicular segments.
questions.explanation_incorrect: L has a horizontal and vertical line meeting at 90 degrees. S, C, and O have curves.

questions.question_text: The region enclosed between two radii and an arc of a circle is called a:
questions.explanation_correct: A sector is the region bounded by two radii and the arc between their endpoints on the circle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Two radii + arc = sector. Chord + arc = segment. Half the circle = semicircle.

questions.question_text: A simple closed curve that is NOT a polygon is:
questions.explanation_correct: A circle is a simple closed curve but NOT a polygon (it has no straight sides). Triangles, squares, and hexagons are polygons.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Polygons are made of straight line segments. A circle is a curved closed figure, not a polygon.

questions.question_text: In a quadrilateral ABCD, the diagonals are:
questions.explanation_correct: Diagonals connect non-adjacent vertices. In ABCD: A and C are non-adjacent, B and D are non-adjacent. So the diagonals are AC and BD.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Adjacent vertices are connected by sides (AB, BC, CD, DA). Non-adjacent vertices are connected by diagonals (AC, BD).

questions.question_text: The minimum number of points needed to determine a unique line is ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Two distinct points determine exactly one line passing through them.
questions.explanation_incorrect: One point has infinitely many lines through it. Two points determine a unique line.

questions.question_text: If the diameter of a circle is 20 cm, the radius is:
questions.explanation_correct: Radius = Diameter / 2 = 20 / 2 = 10 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Radius is half the diameter: 20/2 = 10 cm.

questions.question_text: All perpendicular lines are intersecting lines.
questions.explanation_correct: Perpendicular lines must intersect (at 90 degrees). So all perpendicular lines are intersecting lines. But not all intersecting lines are perpendicular.
questions.explanation_incorrect: To be perpendicular, lines must meet at 90 degrees — so they must intersect. The statement is true.

questions.question_text: How many vertices does a hexagon have?
questions.explanation_correct: A hexagon has 6 sides, 6 vertices, and 6 angles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In any polygon, the number of vertices equals the number of sides. A hexagon has 6 of each.

questions.question_text: How many line segments can be drawn using 4 points (no three collinear)?
questions.explanation_correct: Choose 2 out of 4 points: 4C2 = 4x3/2 = 6 line segments.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Each pair of points gives one segment. 4 points: 4x3/2 = 6 segments.

questions.question_text: How many radii can a circle have?
questions.explanation_correct: A radius can be drawn from the centre to any point on the circle. Since there are infinitely many points on a circle, there are infinitely many radii.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Every point on the circle gives a radius. Since a circle has infinitely many points, there are infinitely many radii.

questions.question_text: How many diagonals does a hexagon have?
questions.explanation_correct: Hexagon (6 sides): diagonals = 6(6-3)/2 = 6x3/2 = 9.
questions.explanation_incorrect: n(n-3)/2 = 6x3/2 = 9 diagonals.

questions.question_text: Which pair of lines from these examples are parallel? (a) Two opposite edges of a ruler (b) Two adjacent sides of a rectangle (c) Two opposite sides of a rectangle
questions.explanation_correct: Opposite edges of a ruler are parallel. Opposite sides of a rectangle are also parallel. Adjacent sides of a rectangle are perpendicular, not parallel.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Adjacent sides of a rectangle meet at 90 degrees (perpendicular). But opposite edges of a ruler and opposite sides of a rectangle never meet — they are parallel.

questions.question_text: A polygon with 8 sides is called an:
questions.explanation_correct: An octagon has 8 sides (octa = eight).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hexagon (6), heptagon (7), octagon (8), nonagon (9). An 8-sided polygon is an octagon.

questions.question_text: A diameter of a circle is also a chord of that circle.
questions.explanation_correct: A chord is any line segment with both endpoints on the circle. A diameter satisfies this definition (and also passes through the centre). So a diameter is a chord — the longest one.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A diameter has both endpoints on the circle, so by definition it is a chord. It is the special case of a chord passing through the centre.

questions.question_text: Two distinct rays with the same starting point always form:
questions.explanation_correct: Two rays sharing a common starting point (vertex) form an angle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Two rays from the same point create an angle. They form a line only if they point in exactly opposite directions.

questions.question_text: The adjacent sides of a quadrilateral PQRS are:
questions.explanation_correct: Adjacent sides share a common vertex. PQ and QR share vertex Q, so they are adjacent.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Adjacent sides share a vertex. PQ and QR share Q. PQ and RS are opposite sides.

questions.question_text: The number of diameters a circle can have is ___.
questions.explanation_correct: A diameter can be drawn through the centre in any direction. Since there are infinitely many directions, there are infinitely many diameters.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A circle has infinitely many diameters, each at a different angle through the centre.

questions.question_text: In a rectangle, opposite sides are ___ and adjacent sides are ___.
questions.explanation_correct: In a rectangle, opposite sides are parallel (equal and never meet) and adjacent sides are perpendicular (meet at 90 degrees).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rectangle: opposite sides are parallel, adjacent sides meet at right angles (perpendicular).

questions.question_text: The interior of a closed curve is the region:

options.text: Both inside and on the curve

questions.explanation_correct: The interior is the enclosed region inside the curve, not including the boundary (curve itself) or the exterior.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Interior = inside only. The curve itself is the boundary. Outside is the exterior.
